articles.title: Gisborne's main street hit by three deliberate palm tree fires in one night
articles.author: Gisborne Herald
articles.summary: Firefighters were called to the main street in Gisborne three times on Tuesday night to put out burning palm trees. The first call came in about 10.30pm to a palm on fire in Gladstone Rd between Bright St and Grey St. Half an hour later there was another call to the same location to another tree on fire.

articles.title: Guest commentary: NOAA cuts put coastal communities at risk
articles.author: Sabrina B. Valenti
articles.summary: For Americans on the Gulf or Atlantic coasts, the daily weather forecast comes with a thrum of worry. Any disturbance in the Atlantic could evolve into a major storm. The palace intrigue, staffing cuts, and general upheaval of the Trump administration could have dire effects for people on these coasts.

articles.title: Bye bye Paris?
articles.author: Milking It
articles.summary: Federated Farmers' Auckland province called for New Zealand to withdraw from the Paris Agreement on Climate Change. Remit has passed and is heading for the Feds' annual conference in Christchurch next week. Other provinces are also sending similar remits to the conference. Two of the directors of DairyNZ are Feds stalwarts.

articles.title: Millions of birds fly over Indiana during migration
articles.author: Brayton Riley
articles.summary: An estimated 16.6 million birds crossed over Indiana to migrate north on Monday night into early Tuesday morning. The middle of May is peak bird migration. The birds migrate north because there is an abundance of space and food for them to hatch their chicks. They mainly travel at night using the stars and moon for direction.

articles.title: NiMET predicts heavy rainfall, warns of cholera outbreaks
articles.author: Wale Akinselure
articles.summary: The Nigerian Meteorological Agency has raised the alarm over the possibility of cholera and other waterborne disease outbreaks in several states in 2025 due to anticipated heavy rainfall and flooding. Lagos, the Federal Capital Territory, Kaduna, Ebonyi, Cross River, Abia, and Akwa Ibom are most at risk, especially in flood-prone areas with poor sanitation practices.

articles.title: Why too much carbon dioxide harms the planet
articles.author: JULIA JACOBO
articles.summary: Carbon dioxide is a heat-trapping gas. It is produced by various natural processes, including respiration in animals and plants, volcanic eruptions, wildfires and decay of organic matter. Human activity since the 1800s is overwhelming the planet's natural carbon sinks, such as oceans and forests. Humans have injected more than 1.5 trillion tons of CO2 into the atmosphere since the Industrial Revolution.

articles.title: Civil defense units must invest in professionalization and resources to prepare for climate risks, warn experts
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: As the effects of climate change intensify in urban areas, it is essential to prepare for the change in climate. It is also necessary to be aware of the weather in urban places. It's also essential to be conscious of the environment in general. It’s essential.

articles.title: Farmer shot dead in St Elizabeth
articles.summary: Winston Gray, 55, a farmer was shot dead in Burnt Savanna, St Elizabeth on Monday night. He was found on a roadway suffering from what appeared to be gunshot wounds and pronounced dead at the hospital. Residents heard loud explosions and shortly after Gray was found.

articles.title: How birds use winds to migrate northward
articles.author: Cameron Saliga
articles.summary: Buckeye State is seeing it's peak bird migration season. This week is the biggest week in birding across Ohio, with a large migration happening near Lake Erie. Large birds fly during the day, while smaller birds fly at night, taking advantage of calmer conditions and with a tailwind.

articles.title: New Study Offers Vital Insights to Enhance Arizona Wildfire and Post-Fire
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: After Wildfire: A Guide for Arizona Communities has been developed to support those grappling with the consequences of wildfires in the state. Wildfires disrupt local ecosystems, infrastructure, and economic activities, creating a cascade of challenges. The guide includes science-based recommendations for property owners and community planners to reduce fuels, establish defensible spaces and implement landscape-level fire mitigation strategies.

articles.title: Austin weather: Temps hit triple digits, 100-year-old daily heat record broken
articles.author: Adam Fullerton
articles.summary: Temperatures hit the triple-digits for the first time this year in Austin shortly after 4 p.m. Tuesday is officially the first 100-degree day of the year. The previous record for May 13 was 98 degrees in 1925. The current record high at Austin-Bergstrom International Airport for May 14 is 96 degrees.

articles.title: Are hurricanes getting stronger and more frequent?
articles.author: Stars Insider
articles.summary: Every hurricane in the 2024 Atlantic season was stronger than it would have been 100 years ago, according to a new report by Climate Central. The report claims that human-driven climate change is to blame for the increase in the number of hurricanes and their intensity.

articles.title: Parent group challenges energy giant over carbon claims
articles.author: Jennifer Dudley-Nicholson
articles.summary: "If we're successful, this could change the behaviour of this particular company and send a clear signal to all companies in Australia who market their products with these sorts of climate claims," he said.       "This could not just change the behavior of this company but also send a really clear signal"

articles.title: Green Fireball in Sky Identified as ‘One Hell of a Meteor' Makes for Nice Mother's Day Surprise
articles.author: Kimberlee Speakman
articles.summary: A green fireball was caught on camera streaking across the sky in Australia on Sunday, May 11 at around 6 a.m. local time. The Perth Observatory identified it as an iron meteor, about the size of a cricket ball to a basketball. It passed over the Central Wheatbelt in Western Australia.

articles.title: USDA Climate Webpages Restored After Lawsuit Victory
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The U.S. Department of Agriculture has reinstated climate change-related webpages that had been removed since former President Donald Trump's tenure. The action comes in response to a lawsuit brought by environmental and farming organizations. The USDA has pledged to restore the resources fully within two weeks.

articles.title: Addressing climate-driven change in Southwest Harbor
articles.summary: Join Gulf of Maine Research Institute at the Southwest Harbor Public Library on Tuesday, May 20 at 11 a.m. and join them for a talk at 5:30 p.m., to explore climate-driven changes in the Gulf and on Mount Desert Island. Find out how to build a more resilient future through community-driven actions such as coastal flooding community science. All are invited to join GMRI on Wednesday, May 21 at 9 am at Manset town dock to engage in the coastal flooding project.

articles.title: Data show Earth continues to get hotter
articles.author: William Bowman
articles.summary: 2024 was the warmest year on record, according to the World Meteorological Organization. The last 10 years, from 2015 to 2024, are the 10 hottest in recorded history, which dates back to the mid-19th century. In the United States, the hottest years have all been recorded since 1998, with 2024 the hottest ever measured.

articles.title: First Climate Change Risk Assessment Report Released For Hawke's Bay
articles.author: Scoop Infopages
articles.summary: This assessment is an important resource, bringing together the best available information and evidence to paint a picture of how the impacts of climate change will likely be experienced across the region, affecting Hawke's Bay places and people. More information is available at: http://www.climateassessment.org/

articles.title: Manitobans scramble to evacuate as new wildfires rage
articles.author: Katherine Dow
articles.summary: A plume of wildfire smoke lingers in the air in Lac du Bonnet, Man. on May 13, 2025, as a result of a wildfire in the area. It was caused by a forest fire.    - Jamie Dowsett/CTV News Winnipeg.

articles.title: Planned ignitions in 2023 wildfires were ‘reasonable,' Forest Practices Board rules
articles.author: The Canadian Press
articles.summary: A fire tornado or fire whirl is seen in a video shot by the BC Wildfire Service at Gun Lake in the B.C. Interior overnight on August 17, 2023. The video has been published by the Peterborough Examiner. The website's domain is: thepeterboroughexaminer.com.

articles.title: Global Warming Has Already Made Natural Habitats Unsurvivable for 2% of Amphibians: Study
articles.author: Paige Bennett
articles.summary: 2% of amphibian species are already experiencing overheating events in their natural habitats. Global warming is expected to reach between 1.9 and 3.7 degrees Celsius by 2100. 41% of all amphibians, totaling over 8,000 species, are listed as threatened with extinction.

articles.title: 'Change is on the way': When farmers in Victoria, SA, Tasmania enduring punishing drought are set to receive rain relief this winter
articles.author: Rob Sharpe
articles.summary: Sydney has seen rain on 20 of the last 22 days. Adelaide has only seen 30mm since January. Farmers in South Australia, Tasmania, much of Victoria and along the country's west coast are struggling through drought. The Indian Ocean has been warmer than usual almost throughout. There is a chance of a negative phase of the Indian Ocean Dipole (-IOD) coming from the west.

articles.title: Massive wildfires in Canada helped keep the world cooler in 2023
articles.author: Michael Le Page
articles.summary: 2023 smashed the record for the hottest year, but it might have been even hotter. The entire northern hemisphere would have been nearly 1°C warmer on average without the cooling effect of smoke from massive wildfires in Canada. The smoke may have led to the driest August in India on record.

articles.title: California senator calls on NOAA to restore 'billion-dollar' disaster database
articles.author: Reuters
articles.summary: NOAA removed the database that tracks billion-dollar U.S. disasters from its website. Adam Schiff says it prevents lawmakers, insurance companies and taxpayers from seeing the growing cost of more frequent natural disasters and planning for future extreme weather events. He also warned that sweeping job cuts at NOAA have left the agency understaffed ahead of hurricane season.

articles.title: STEM careers are crucial to combat climate change
articles.author: Independent online
articles.summary: There are three international days dedicated to the environment from April to June this year. The focus is on the environment and on humanity's responsibility to curtail the effects of climate change on the planet. International Mother Earth Day is commemorated on April 22, 2014.

articles.title: A training for the media on climate change issues was held in Ashgabat
articles.author: Svetlana Chirtsova
articles.summary: On May 12 in Ashgabat, journalists from Turkmenistan, Tajikistan, Uzbekistan, Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan took part in a training on the causes, consequences and measures to fight against global warming. The main objective of the training was to improve the professional skills of journalists covering environmental issues.

articles.title: When will life on earth end forever? Scientists share chilling prediction you need to know
articles.author: ET Online
articles.summary: A study using supercomputer simulations has provided a chilling timeline for the end of life on Earth. According to the simulations, Earth's oxygen levels will start to decline rapidly in just one billion years, marking the point at which life as we know it will cease. Rising temperatures and increasing global temperatures, driven by both natural and human-made factors, are already accelerating the changes predicted by the simulations.

articles.title: NASA study anticipates Earth's breathable atmosphere fading roughly one billion years into future
articles.author: Tags
articles.summary: NASA-backed study predicts Earth's oxygen supply will deplete in roughly one billion years due to an escalating solar heating trend. The Sun's natural brightening will destabilize CO? levels, triggering irreversible desertification and oxygen loss. Only anaerobic microbes will survive in the barren, UV-exposed environment. The study refines how scientists search for life on other planets.

articles.title: IMD Announces Onset Of Monsoon Over South Bay of Bengal, Nicobar Islands; Early Rainy Season Expected In Kerala
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: The southwest monsoon advanced into parts of the south Bay of Bengal, south Andaman Sea, Nicobar Islands and some areas of the north andaman Sea on Tuesday. The primary rain bearing system is likely to reach Kerala on May 27, earlier than the usual date of June 1.

articles.title: PACT Secures Re-Accreditation to Global Climate Fund
articles.author: hipolito
articles.summary: The Protected Areas Conservation Trust (PACT) has been re-accredited as a National Implementing Entity of the Adaptation Fund for another five years. Since first being accredited in 2011, PACT has mobilized over BZ$18.3 million for climate resilience and adaptation projects across Belize. The organization aims to raise an additional $40 million during the new cycle.

articles.title: This Is Who's Causing Global Warming, According to Science
articles.author: Luis Prada
articles.summary: The richest 10 percent of humans are responsible for two-thirds of global warming since 1990. The top 1% are responsible 20 times more than the rest of the population. The poorest 50% produce 10% of global emissions. The rich and powerful are mostly to blame for climate change.

articles.title: Over 84,000 people affected by Somalia floods since mid-April: UN
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Floods in Somalia killed at least 17 people and affected more than 84,000 people since mid-April. The Horn of Africa is one of the most vulnerable regions to climate change and extreme weather events are becoming more frequent and intense. More rain is expected in the coming days across southern and central Somalia.

articles.title: Antarctic Ice Is Increasing…Climate Models 'No Longer Reflect Reality'
articles.author: P Gosselin
articles.summary: Antarctica's continental ice is increasing again. Arctic sea ice has not decreased for over 10 years. Climate model forecasts are deviating from reality. Prof. Bjorn Stevens and Prof. Jochem Marotzke speak of a crisis in climate science. This is the moment for a paradigm shift.

articles.title: Letter: Your voice matters — Support the San Ramon Climate Action Plan
articles.author: Readers
articles.summary: The Planning Commission recommended the City Council adopt the draft San Ramon Climate Action Plan (CAP). The CAP is open for public comment until 5 p.m. on Thursday, May 15. The CAP addresses the urgent need for mitigation against the escalating risks of global heating here in Contra Costa County.

articles.title: It's peak spring migration season in Chicago, and residents can help birds arrive safely by turning their lights off at night
articles.author: Michael Johnson
articles.summary: BirdCast says nearly 31 million birds have been estimated to have migrated into Cook County from March 1 through the overnight hours of Monday into Tuesday. The peak was reached around 2:30 a.m. Tuesday, when an estimated 425,100 birds crossed into the county at an altitude of 2,200 feet and a speed of 30 miles per hour. The highest nightly traffic was recorded on Friday, May 9, when 346,900 birds were in flight, on average, at one time. Chicago is on 'high migration alert' this week, which includes overnight Tuesday into Wednesday.

articles.title: CLIMATE DATA MANIPULATION published in blogs KEY to CLIMATE CHANGE MYTH now exposed in new book
articles.author: Natural News
articles.summary: The IPCC and climate activists have repeatedly used a misleading climate change graphic that exaggerates modern warming. The graphic has been traced to an Australian activist group rather than peer-reviewed science. The IPCC faces accusations of prioritizing alarmist narratives to secure funding and policy influence. Past scandals like 'Climategate' have eroded public trust in climate institutions.

articles.title: RV, home total losses after Lakeville, N.S., fire
articles.author: Natalie Lombard
articles.summary: An RV and house are on fire in Lakeville, N.S., on May 13, 2025, according to Bill Roberts. The cause of the fire is not yet known, but it is suspected to be caused by an electrical fault.

articles.title: Let's Make Our Cities and Communities Bird-Friendly
articles.author: Alex Ngari
articles.summary: This year's World Migratory Bird Day theme is 'Creating Bird-Friendly Cities and Communities'. It highlights the need for healthy coexistence between birds and humans in the face of expanding urban developments, made worse by the changing climate. According to a 2024 study, urbanisation has led to a decrease in the variety of birds species and shrinking their roles in the ecosystem. Light pollution can interfere with the natural environment adversely impacting birds and other species.

articles.title: Watauga EDC opens business snapshot survey
articles.author: Watauga Democrat
articles.summary: The Watauga County Economic Development Commission has opened its reporting window for its April 2025 Business Snapshot Report. It's an effort to track real-time conditions for local businesses as recovery from the impacts of Hurricane Helene continues to continue.   .

articles.title: How ancient humans survived a global climate disaster 8200 years ago
articles.author: Christa Lesté-Lasserre
articles.summary: Plummeting temperatures forced some human populations to adapt to the new conditions thousands of years ago, but the changes they made varied widely. Christa Lesté-Lasserre explains how ancient humans survived a global climate disaster 8200 years ago.

articles.title: Maryland DNR Expands Focus to All Watersheds
articles.author: David M. Higgins II
articles.summary: Maryland Department of Natural Resources has rebranded its Chesapeake and coastal service as Watershed and Climate Services effective May 13, 2025. The new name reflects the unit's commitment to building resilient ecosystems, supporting vibrant economies, and enhancing well-being of Marylanders through science-driven solutions. Climate change is one of the most pressing issues facing Maryland today.

articles.title: WATCH/READ: A Puppet Parade For Climate Alarm (Yes, it is real)
articles.author: David Blackmon
articles.summary: The climate alarm organizers in the Congo convinced native citizens to participate in a project to raise awareness about their religious dogma-driven fantasies about the looming 'climate catastrophe'. The project is not a pending update to the stage production of 'The Lion King' but some deranged person's idea of 'art'.

articles.title: What can Afrikaners expect in their new homes in Idaho, Iowa, and North Carolina?
articles.author: Sarene Kloren
articles.summary: Afrikaans-speaking farmers are moving to the United States. They will settle in Idaho, Iowa and North Carolina. Each state has its own agricultural communities, and industries. Idaho is famous for potatoes, wheat, barley, sugar beets, hay, and milk production. Iowa's fertile soil and favourable climate conditions make it an ideal location for large-scale farming operations. North Carolina's agriculture is diverse, producing tobacco, sweet potatoes and poultry.

articles.title: Ghana's Rainfall Pattern: Single Or Double Peak Or What?
articles.summary: Ghana has had its share of climate change. The Agricultural Advisory Council, which was abolished, should be reconstituted to advise government on agriculture. The current climate change calls for a review of the nation's agriculture. It is time to study the past weather records to know how Ghana's weather pattern has changed since the colonial masters came out.

articles.title: How climate change is impacting the banana
articles.author: Dc Correspondent
articles.summary: Two-thirds of banana cultivation areas in Latin America and the Caribbean may become unsuitable for farming by 2080 due to climate change. Extreme weather, rising temperatures, and climate-related pests severely impact banana-growing countries like Guatemala, Costa Rica, and Colombia. The situation has reduced yields and devastated rural communities throughout the region, as highlighted in Christian Aid's report.

articles.title: San Francisco's coldest days are getting warmer
articles.author: Nadia Lopez
articles.summary: Thirty-year average coldest temperatures are rising almost universally nationwide, including in San Francisco. Spring is getting warmer as extreme heat events become more frequent and intense. In the west, Reno, Nevada had the biggest increase, followed by Las Vegas (+8.9°F) and Fresno (+5.2°F).

articles.title: Norfolk records highest sea-level rise on the East Coast — again
articles.author: Daily Press
articles.summary: Norfolk is near the top of the list for sea-level rise. The fastest rate of rise is in Gulf states like Texas and Louisiana, but East Coast stations are accelerating. This is probably due to patterns of water distribution related to glacial melt from the Greenland ice sheet.

articles.title: Extreme Weather, Climate Change Impacts Hit Africa Hard
articles.author: Ahmed Emam
articles.summary: Extreme weather and climate change impacts are hitting every aspect of socio-economic development in Africa. The past decade has been the warmest on record. Marine heatwaves impacted the biggest area since measurements started in 1993. Artificial intelligence, mobile communication tools and advanced weather prediction models are enhancing the accuracy and reach of weather services across Africa.

articles.title: John Wheeler: Past natural climate change raises concern about future climate change
articles.author: The Daily Republic
articles.summary: The Carnian Pluvial Episode occurred 234 million years ago during the late Triassic Period. The climate of our planet has been anything but static since then, as the records show.   Â   i   in this case, it was a period of climate upheaval during the Carnian pluvial episode.

articles.title: Global warming: The wealthiest 10% are responsible for two thirds of the phenomenon
articles.author: Audrey Garric
articles.summary: Katy Perry's trip to space in April burned a lot of CO 2. The richest 10% of the world are responsible for two thirds of global warming since 1990. The poorest 50% are responsible only 12% of global greenhouse gas emissions. The wealthiest 10% emitted 48% of greenhouse gas emissions in 2019, according to the study.

articles.title: Elon Musk and the Cargo Shorts Brigade Have Cut Funding for Ocean Research When We Need It Most
articles.author: Charles P. Pierce
articles.summary: Since 1993, satellites have kept careful watch over the world's oceans. Sea level rise was unexpectedly high last year, according to NASA analysis of satellite data. The rate of annual sea level rise has more than doubled in the last 2,000 years. President Trump wants to strip back agencies tasked with monitoring the oceans.

articles.title: Norfolk records highest sea-level rise on the East Coast — again
articles.author: Eliza Noe
articles.summary: Norfolk is near the top of the list for sea-level rise. Grand Isle, Louisiana, took the nation's top spot. Texas had two cities in the top five, with Rockport and Galveston taking second and third place respectively. The fastest rate of rise is in Gulf states, but East Coast stations are accelerating.

articles.title: The world's hottest city - 54C and 'you have to hide from the sun'
articles.author: Grace Piercy
articles.summary: Kuwait City is the hottest city in the world, with a temperature of 54C. It is getting hotter due to climate change. Two-thirds of home electricity consumption in Kuwait derives from running air conditioning units. The incidence of heat-related mortalities could rise by 5.1% to 11.7% across Kuwait's residents by the end of this century.

articles.title: Immigration rate is ‘choking' Australia: Andrew Bolt
articles.summary: Sky News host Andrew Bolt discusses the 'massive problem' of overpopulation in Australia. Mr Bolt says the high rate of immigration in Australia will become a 'theme' this year. He compares Australia's population growth to the rest of the world's and questions if anyone wants to live in a land where people share no history.

articles.title: Farne Islands' seabird spectacular to be shown on webcams
articles.author: Tom Wilkinson
articles.summary: Ms Jackson says regular monitoring of seabird populations is important for conservation work on the islands and for keeping track of the impacts of climate change through warming seas and more frequent storms, as well as for monitoring the different seabirds' populations, despite different methodologies.

articles.title: Bananas on brink: Climate change threatens global favorite
articles.author: Daily Sabah With Aa
articles.summary: Two-thirds of banana-growing areas in Latin America and the Caribbean may become unsuitable for banana production by 2080 due to the effects of climate change. Christian Aid has called on wealthy nations to reduce their fossil fuel consumption and financially support countries struggling to adapt to the climate crisis.

articles.title: Scientists exploring how to beat heat for better sleep
articles.author: Isabelle Cortes
articles.summary: Rising temperatures are affecting sleep quality due to climate change. The human brain is sensitive to heat, with higher temperatures raising the central thermostat and activating stress systems. Scientists are exploring ways to help the body adapt to rising temperatures without harming sleep quality.

articles.title: Going bananas: New report shows how climate change threatens world's favourite fruit
articles.author: Mrityunjay Bose
articles.summary: Extreme weather, rising temperatures and climate related pests pose a threat to banana producing regions, according to analysis. There are calls for faster emission cuts and more support for farmers, as well as for farmers to be given more time to adapt to the changing climate.

articles.title: The climate war of exaggeration has to be stopped
articles.author: Joe Bastardi
articles.summary: In May, global temperatures are warmest where no one lives and coolest where people do. Eastern South America and Southeast China are densely populated and warm, while the US, India, and Europe are relatively cool. The Arctic and Antarctica contribute significantly to the global warmth. The UK is a strong advocate for net-zero policies.

articles.title: Colchester one of 8 cities to see 29-day increase in pollen season
articles.author: Séamus O'Hanlon
articles.summary: The hayfever season has increased across the country over the past three decades. From 1994 to 2024, England has seen an average 20-day increase in the pollen season, with 131 cities registering an increase of at least 21 days. Colchester, Plymouth, Brentwood, Hornchurch, Grays, Romford, Basildon, and Weymouth experience the highest increase of 29 days. East of England led the regions with nearly a 25 days increase.

articles.title: Spider surge in summer: Why you are seeing more & what to do
articles.author: Siddhartha Jana
articles.summary: Spiders are attracted to warm weather because it increases bug populations. They also mate throughout the summer, which increases the frequency of sightings in this time of the year. Spiders are also attracted to warmer weather because they mate during the summer.

articles.title: Cordilleran Ice Sheet Meltwater Released 20-17k Years Ago
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: The Cordilleran Ice Sheet retreated from western North America between 20,000 and 17,000 years ago. New evidence from a karstified glacial outwash plain reveals a semi-continuous pulse of meltwater discharge from the ice sheet. The study combines optically stimulated luminescence (OSL) dating methods with uranium-thorium dating on carbonate deposits formed within the karST system.

articles.title: The threat to our climate is still not being taken seriously enough
articles.author: The Yorkshire Post Letters
articles.summary: Ann Forsaith is concerned about climate change and wants to inform her readers that they are not alone in their concern. Studies show that between 80 and 89 per cent of the world's population want to see strong action being taken by their Governments to tackle the climate crisis.

articles.title: Heavy rainfall ahead as NiMet predicts up to 290 rainy days in Southern Nigeria for 2025
articles.author: Ripples Nigeria
articles.summary: Nigeria's southern coastal states are in for a long and wet year, according to the 2025 Seasonal Climate Prediction released by the Nigerian Meteorological Agency (NiMet) on Monday. In the north, rainfall will be limited, with annual totals expected to fall below 685 mm, rainy days projected between 110 and 150, and dry spells of up to 21 days.

articles.title: Planning Department reminds the public of upcoming events
articles.author: The Garden Island
articles.summary: The Planning Department reminds and invites the public to attend two upcoming events regarding the Kauai Climate Action and Action Plan (KCAAP) and the East Kauai Community Plan. On Tuesday, May 13, from 4:30 to 7 p.m. at the Kalukalu Economic Resilience Center in Kapaa, community members can review the draft KCAAP and participate in a Climate Change Hazards Workshop. On Thursday, May 15, from 5 to 7 pm at the Hanapepe Public Library, residents will have the opportunity to review and provide feedback on the draft plan.

articles.title: First-Of-Its-Kind Surgery Uses Eye Socket To Remove Spinal Cancer
articles.summary: There is a slight chance of a rain shower this afternoon. The weather will be partly cloudy, with a high of 77F. Winds will be light and variable. Tonight there are some clouds, but there will be some decrease in clouds late. The temperature will drop to around 60F.

articles.title: Why do birds fly in V shape?
articles.author: Sweta Gupta
articles.summary: Migratory birds often fly in a V-shape to conserve energy during long migrations. The lead bird works the hardest, while the ones behind take advantage of the airflow it creates. Researchers fitted ibises with trackers and found that they fly about a metre behind and to the side of the bird in front.

articles.title: Manitoba's hot, dry weather could put farmers, firefighters to the test
articles.summary: There has been a record-breaking heat wave in recent days in Manitoba. Weather experts warn of trouble ahead for firefighters and farmers due to hot and dry conditions so far this season in Manitoba and a possible wildfire season.      Â

articles.title: John Wheeler: Past natural climate change raises concern about future climate change
articles.author: In Louisiana
articles.summary: John Wheeler is Chief Meteorologist for WDAY since May of 1985. He grew up in the South, in Louisiana and Alabama. He attended Iowa State University and achieved a B.S. degree in Meteorology in 1984. He worked for WOI-TV in central Iowa before moving to Fargo and WDAY.

articles.title: John Wheeler: Past natural climate change raises concern about future climate change
articles.author: In Louisiana
articles.summary: The Carnian Pluvial Episode, 234 million years ago, caused a dramatic change in the climate of Earth. The geological record offers evidence of numerous climate upheavals throughout prehistory. Climatologists recognize that chemical changes to the atmosphere are capable of changing the state of the Earth's climate.

articles.title: Southwest monsoon reaches Nicobar Islands and Bay of Bengal ahead of schedule
articles.summary: The southwest monsoon has made a significant advance, reaching parts of the south Bay of Bengal, south Andaman Sea, Nicobar Islands, and parts of north Andaman sea. The IMD expects the monsoon to reach Kerala by May 27, five days ahead of the usual onset date of June 1.

articles.title: Solutions to the climate crisis have one key: investment
articles.author: José L García
articles.summary: According to OECD, Mexico is a country that suffers disproportionately from the consequences of climate change. Extreme weather events related to climate change have increased and their frequency and intensity are expected to continue to rise. The recent hurricanes Otis and John hit the state of Guerrero twice in the space of two years. The combination of extreme droughts and exceptionally high temperatures has increased pressure on water sources in various regions. There is an urgent need to invest in environmental solutions focused on both climate change adaptation and mitigation. These investments are strategic for the public sector, philanthropy and organised communities.

articles.title: Monsoon reaches south Bay of Bengal, Nicobar Islands: IMD
articles.author: PTI
articles.summary: The southwest monsoon advanced into the south Bay of Bengal, south Andaman Sea, Nicobar Islands and some areas of the north andaman Sea on Tuesday (May 13, 2025). The primary rain bearing system is likely to reach Kerala on May 27, earlier than the usual date of June 1.

articles.title: Sea levels in Hampton Roads continue to rise, but at a steady pace
articles.author: WHRO
articles.summary: Hampton Roads continues to see rising tides linked to climate change and sinking land, but the rate of change in recent years has stayed in line with past forecasts, according to the latest 'sea level rise report card' from William & Mary's Batten School and Virginia Institute of Marine Science. Most locations showed continued acceleration, including Hampton Roads, where water levels crept up by 5.6 millimeters each year over the past five years. The Gulf Coast is experiencing the fastest acceleration, such as in Texas and Louisiana.

articles.title: Urban temps turning cities into 'ovens,' UN Chief Heat Officer warns
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Eleni Myrivili is the Global Chief Heat Officer for UN-Habitat. She believes that cities are the "Ground Zero of heat" and need to be redesigned to cope with the changing climate. In Athens, she worked on the categorization of extreme heat and created heat campaigns to protect the most vulnerable.

articles.title: Canada has turned to Australia as its relationship with the US crumbles
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Canada is turning to Australia for help in beefing up its defence of the Arctic. It has raised eyebrows in the defence industry, which is concerned about the need to beef up the Arctic defence.      Â   in the industry.

articles.title: Climate should take precedence in protests against Trump
articles.summary: Jim Sawyer has been to rallies and meetings protesting Donald Trump's assault on American democracy. He is concerned about Trump's attack on every facet of climate catastrophe prevention. He has terminated scientists and climate experts working on a critical national climate assessment and pulled the United States out of virtually every global climate accord. He also green-lighted the fossil fuel and petroleum industries to renew oil drilling.

articles.title: Scientists exploring how to beat heat for better sleep
articles.author: Dawn
articles.summary: The human brain is sensitive to heat. Rising temperatures caused by climate change and urbanisation pose a planetary threat to human sleep. Scientists say we need to learn how to adapt to the changing climate and adapt to a cooler, cooler sleep quality.

articles.title: Two types of drinks should be avoided before bed on hot nights to help with sleep, scientists say
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Before bedtime, it is recommended to take a cool shower, reduce stimulants like coffee and limit alcohol. Napping during the hottest hours of the day has been proven to mitigate the impacts of a sleep deficit. Global warming could lead to an annual loss of 50 to 58 hours of sleep per person by 2099.

articles.title: Global displacement reaches record high of 83.4 milllion in past year
articles.author: Fidel Rahmati
articles.summary: In 2024, global displacement surged to a record 83.4 million, driven by war, natural disasters, and climate change impacts. Sudan tops the global displacement list, with over 11.6 million internally displaced people, registering a new record for the country in 2024. International humanitarian agencies face mounting challenges, especially after U.S. foreign aid reductions.

articles.title: Health Dept to be renamed, take on disability in second Albanese ministry
articles.summary: The second Albanese ministry was sworn in on Tuesday morning at Government House. The Department of Climate Change was reconstituted among a number of other major changes when Labor first came to office in 2022. The changes pale in comparison to the major changes that Labor made when it came to power.

articles.title: City of Birmingham Invites Community to Help Shape Climate Action Plan
articles.author: The Birmingham Times
articles.summary: The Central Alabama region is witnessing the undeniable impacts of climate change. There are floods, droughts, extreme heat, tornadoes, and wildfires in the area. The weather is getting worse due to climate change, according to the Birmingham Times' report.

articles.title: Drought and Rising Costs Threaten Nigeria's Agricultural Heartland
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Nigerian farmers are facing climate change-related problems. The consequences are being felt as far south as Lagos, where food prices have surged. The United Nations has suggested techniques like drip irrigation to conserve water and ensure food security. However, economic and infrastructural obstacles hinder widespread adoption.

articles.title: Seasonal Allergies: Climate Change Impact – Archyde: Latest World News, Economy, Entertainment, Health, Technology & Sports Updates
articles.author: archyde
articles.summary: Seasonal allergies are caused by tree and grass pollen. Climate change has lengthened pollen seasons and increased pollen potency. Mould spores are another airborne allergen that can cause allergies. Many people rely on antihistamines and nasal corticosteroid sprays for seasonal allergies. Allergy immunotherapy can reduce allergy symptoms by up to 85%.

articles.title: Land squeeze threatens climate-exposed islanders
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: The Walande community in the Solomon Islands is running out of space to grow food and build homes due to climate change-fuelled extreme weather. They were forced to move to the mainland more than a decade ago. The 50-hectare plot on the mainland is not enough for 800 people. The community made the move with little financial support from the national government or international donors.

articles.title: Land squeeze threatens climate-exposed islanders

articles.title: Land squeeze threatens climate-exposed islanders
articles.author: Poppy Johnston
articles.summary: The Walande community in the Solomon Islands is running out of space to grow food and build homes due to sea level rise. The 50-hectare plot on the mainland is not enough for 800 people. The community made the move with little financial support from the national government or international donors. The Solomon Islands government is one of six with guidelines for planned relocation.

articles.title: Heat Persists for Australia's Coral Reefs Despite Winter
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: Lord Howe Island is home to the world's southernmost coral reef. It's at the crossroads of five major ocean currents, including the East Australian Current. It is a biodiversity hotspot and a key site for understanding how coral reefs might adapt in a warming world.

articles.title: Galena, JDCF to collaborate for World Migratory Bird Day event
articles.author: Telegraph Herald
articles.summary: The city of Galena and Jo Daviess Conservation Foundation will collaborate for an upcoming celebration of World Migratory Bird Day. The celebration will take place on Saturday, May 17, at the Galena River Trailhead under the U.S. 20 bridge.

articles.title: Commissioners hear about emergency management goals
articles.summary: Charlotte County Emergency Management Director Patrick Fuller gives commissioners insights into recovery and resilience during a public services workshop Monday. The county has been dealing with a string of disasters on a regular basis for five years. The hurricane season starts on June 1.

articles.title: Protect the Southern Highlands' wildlife by choosing sustainable firewood
articles.author: Staff Reporters
articles.summary: Temperatures are dropping across the Southern Highlands. Wingecarribee Shire Council reminds residents to collect firewood responsibly to help protect the region's unique natural environment. Fallen timber plays a vital role in the local ecosystem. It provides shelter and nesting sites for native animals, including echidnas, lizards, and small marsupials. To protect the long-term health of native flora and fauna, collecting firewood from Council bushland reserves and roadsides is not permitted.

articles.title: Jashore hatcheries suffer as temperatures soar
articles.author: Mohsin Milon
articles.summary: Temperatures in Chanchra in Jashore have hovered around 40 degrees Celsius for the past week. The heat is affecting the production of fry (renu) and fingerlings (fry) in the area. The district fisheries department has advised hatchery owners to supply adequate water to reservoirs, cultivate aquatic plants like sedges and plant banana and papaya trees along the banks to provide shade.

articles.title: Global and interplanetary view of the biggest geomagnetic storm in 20 years
articles.author: Harsh Vardhan
articles.summary: The geomagnetic storm disrupted the planting season. Several trans-Atlantic flights had to be rerouted mid-journey to keep crew and passengers safe. GPS and high-frequency radio systems over polar routes were disrupted. NASA's Ice, Cloud, and land Elevation Satellite-2 (ICESat-2) lost elevation and switched to safe mode. Colorado Inner Radiation Belt Experiment (CIRBE) was pulled out of orbit months earlier than planned.

articles.title: City of Birmingham Invites Community to Help Shape Climate Action Plan
articles.author: Birmingham Times
articles.summary: The first of several community engagement meetings will take place today, May 13 at 5:30 p.m. at the Homewood Public Library. The Central Alabama Climate Action Plan team is spearheading the development of a comprehensive Plan to address both current and future climate challenges. The team is also conducting a survey to gather community feedback.

articles.title: Brazil's Crops and Antarctic Ice Expose Climate Corruption

articles.title: Colchester one of 8 cities to see 29-day increase in pollen season
articles.author: Séamus O'Hanlon
articles.summary: The hayfever season has increased across the country over the past three decades. From 1994 to 2024, England has seen an average 20-day increase in the pollen season, with 131 cities registering an increase of at least 21 days. Eight cities including Colchester, Plymouth, Brentwood, Hornchurch, Grays, Romford, Basildon, and Weymouth experience the highest increase of 29 days. The East of England led the regions with nearly a 25 days increase.

articles.title: Antarctic Ice's Surprise Rebound: Why Global Citizens Shouldn't Breathe Easy Yet
articles.summary: Antarctica's ice sheet gained 108 gigatons per year from 2021 to 2023, trimming global sea level rise by 0.3 mm annually. East Antarctic glacier basins were previously among the continent's fastest losers. A spike in snowfall, driven by unusual atmospheric and oceanic patterns, dumped enough snow to tip the balance. The long-term outlook for Antarctica is still grim.

articles.title: Record-Breaking Heat Strikes Plains; High Temperatures Expected in ND, SD, MN, TX
articles.author: Golden Gate Media
articles.summary: Record-breaking heat is set to persist across the Northern Plains and spread into the Southern Plains. High temperatures are expected to shatter records in areas including North Dakota, South Dakota, Minnesota, and parts of central Texas through Wednesday. Dry air, gusty winds, and low humidity are raising fire weather risks across the Upper Mississippi Valley, Northern Plains, and Southwest. The NWS has issued Red Flag Warnings in these regions affecting more than 10 million people.

articles.title: Climate Crisis Deepens Across Africa: Record Heat, Deadly Floods, and Droughts Threaten Development
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: The year 2024 ranked as either the warmest or second-warmest on record globally, with Africa experiencing its warmest decade to date. The Atlantic Ocean and Mediterranean Sea saw exceptional warming, and marine heatwaves affected nearly 30 million km² from January to April 2024. Southern Africa suffered some of the worst drought conditions in decades, with cereal yields falling 43–50% below average, while in West and Central Africa, over four million people were impacted by extensive floods. The report highlights a growing digital transformation across Africa's weather and climate services.

articles.title: 60% of banana growing areas hit by climate change globally
articles.author: The Hans India
articles.summary: 60 per cent of banana growing areas in Latin America and the Caribbean could be lost by 2080 due to rising temperatures and extreme weather. India is one of the largest producers of banana in the world with 29.7 million tonnes from an area of 0.88 million hectares with a productivity of 37 MT/ha.

articles.title: Report: 86% of small WNC farms damaged by Hurricane Helene
articles.author: FOX Carolina News Staff
articles.summary: Helene damaged 86 percent of small farms in Western North Carolina. The average cleanup and recovery cost was $40,000. 62 percent of farms reported lost 2024 sales due to product loss, and 39 percent anticipated they would miss out on 2025 sales once rebuilt. 60 percent reported losses due to market outlet closures, and 28 percent expected to lose sales in 2025.

articles.title: Climate war
articles.author: Malik Amin Aslam Khan
articles.summary: Pakistan and India have temporarily avoided a climate war. The whole South Asian region is at risk of the five deadliest impacts including floods, droughts, heatwaves, forest fires and freak hurricanes. Water, or lack of it, is the central triggering factor for most of these impacts. The Indus Waters Treaty (IWT) already provides a robust platform for cooperation.

articles.title: Heavy rains causing widespread destruction in Haiti
articles.summary: Heavy rains have caused widespread flooding in Haiti's Nord-Est Department. More than 4,300 families have been affected since May 5 and more than 3,900 homes were inundated. The United Nations Office for the Coordination of Humanitarian Affairs is supporting local authorities to coordinate the response.

articles.author: Charles P. Pierce
articles.summary: The seas are rising faster than ever because of human-caused global warming. The rate of annual sea level rise has more than doubled over the past 30 years. The US coastlines are tracking above global average and toward the upper end of climate model projections. The Gulf Coast, where land is sinking due to extraction of oil, gas and groundwater, is a hotspot.

articles.author: Express News Service
articles.summary: The length of India's coastline is 3,582.21 km longer than that recorded in 1970, bringing the total to 11,098.81 km. The 1970 data was computed using manual methods at a scale of 1:45,00,000 or smaller, while the new survey measured at 1:2,50,000 and used modern GPS and satellite imagery.

articles.author: Business Journal
articles.summary: As climate change reshapes life in Puget Sound, the call for climate-smart building construction is louder than ever. There are heavier winter storms and smoky summer skies in the area due to climate change, so builders need to be more aware of their surroundings.

articles.title: Get ready for a 'green up': Here's how all the rain could impact SC's wildfire and drought risk
articles.author: File/Janet Morgan/Staff
articles.summary: It's been a soggy couple of days for much of South Carolina, including along the coast. The deluges are helping reduce wildfire risks. The official drought monitor report won't be out until later this week, but meteorologists are confident the rain will help wash away the area's dry conditions.

articles.title: Nepal holds tribute for disappearing glacier
articles.author: AFP
articles.summary: Dozens trekked to Nepal's Yala glacier for a ceremony on Monday to mark its rapid disappearance due to climate change. Since 1974, the glacier has shrunk in area by 66 percent and retreated 784 meters. Scientists warn it may disappear by the 2040s if the warming trend continues.

articles.title: First Climate Change Risk Assessment Report Released For Hawke's Bay
articles.summary: The Climate Change Risk Assessment report for Hawke's Bay is the first of its kind for the region. It was commissioned by the Climate Action Joint Committee (CAJC), made up of local and regional council representatives and tangata whenua leaders, working together to drive co-ordinated regional climate action. The report assesses regional climate change risks across six categories: risk to the natural environment, built environment, human, economic, governance and iwi Māori.

articles.title: Lobby petition UN to have Kenya prepare adequately for climate disaster
articles.author: GORDON OSEN
articles.summary: Coalition of human rights organisations is calling on the government to act decisively by stockpiling supplies and improving disaster preparedness. The 2014-2018 drought affected 23 of Kenya's 47 counties. About 3.4 million Kenyans experienced severe food insecurity and about 500,000 lacked access to water.

articles.title: Weather Department Forecasts Heavy Rainfall in Tamil Nadu Starting Tomorrow
articles.summary: The Weather Department has predicted that Tamil Nadu will experience heavy rainfall starting tomorrow. The department has issued a warning for several regions of the state, including Chennai and coastal areas. A low-pressure area forming over the Bay of Bengal is expected to bring strong rain and winds. The weather system is likely to affect different parts of Tamil Nadu, especially the northern and central regions. The government has increased its readiness to respond to any emergencies.

articles.title: Global warming linked to world's richest 10%
articles.author: Namibian Sun
articles.summary: The wealthiest 10% of the world's people are responsible for two-thirds of the global warming since 1990. articles.title: NOAA Announces its Billion-Dollar Disasters Database 'Retired'
articles.author: Dawn Kitterman
articles.summary: NOAA's National Centers for Environmental Information is retiring a database that tracks natural disasters with significant financial impact. The database provides information on weather-related disasters that caused at least $1 billion in damages from 1980 to 2024. Last year, the United States experienced 27 weather related events, the losses of each exceeding $1billion. According to NOAA data, last year's hurricane season resulted in more than $30 billion in Florida alone.
